intro: Haplopappus pinnatifidus, commonly known as the narrowleaf horseweed, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads composed of numerous small florets. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and disturbed soils. Its leaves are narrow and deeply lobed, and the flowers are small and yellowish, appearing in clusters. Haplopappus pinnatifidus is often found in arid regions and is adapted to thrive in low-nutrient environments.
